home.about: I am a computational biologist currently working as a postdoc in a joint lab between University of Tennessee and Oak Ridge National Laboratory. I enjoy working on genomics, analyzing sequences and building scientific tools. The ultimate aim of my research is to understand the complex cellular pathways, disease-causing mutations by using the evolutionary information. I believe that a huge amount of information resides in the sequence data, which needs to be converted to knowledge. This is where I step into the game.

timeline.title: Middle School Years
timeline.text: Unlike public schools, Izmir Turkish Private School provided me the first experience in a scientific laboratory. These years also have a special importance in shaping my future. I remember preparing a term homework about human genome project. My biology teacher liked the work and asked me to present this to hundreds of people. It was the first time that I got interested about genetics.

timeline.title: High school years
timeline.text: The historic Izmir Ataturk High School was a great place to be a student. What I gained here besides education was the friendships which have been sustainable so far.

timeline.title: College years
text: The Middle East Technical University was the desired place to live at for many high school students. METU expanded my view about life thanks to its tradition about making people feel responsible. This fact was  due to the students and some faculty. Environment in METU was exceptional in terms of understanding the life and people.

I spent a short time with Dr. Cagdas Son and learned about G protein coupled receptors. It was the first time that I was exposed to this protein family, which is likely to be inspiration of my current interest in them.

In my senior year, I worked with Dr. Yesim Aydin Son. She included me in the iGEM software team. I mostly contributed in this group in idea exchange as well as presenting synthetic biology-bioinformatics collaboration in the scientific community.

timeline.title: Industrial internship
timeline.text: I worked at a local diagnostics company: GENMAR. I acted as an intern technician and I learned about practical applications of the biotechnology products. Because the aim was to help scientists, it was not exciting at all. Why would I watch science instead of getting involved?

timeline.title: Scientific internship
timeline.text: I earned a scholarship from Radboud University in Netherlands to spend some time for my internship there. I went there with my two friends (who are also pursuing academic careers). I worked with Tony Rosciolli and Jo Huiqing Zhou on cleft lip palate. It was the first serious scientific work that I performed.

timeline.title: Applications for future career
timeline.text: The application package must be tailored for each program and/or university. If you do it thoroughly, it takes time. If you increase the application number, they might look sloppy. I decided to make "good" applications to few places. I applied to three universities only and got offers by two of them.

timeline.title: VOLS years
text: I joined Genome Science and Technology program jointly hosted by the University of Tennessee and Oak Ridge National Laboratory. UT was my main location in my first year, where I had four rotations in different laboratories. It was probably one of the most diverse rotation choices.
First, I started working with Dr. Brynn Voy on an exciting project investigating the low-dose radiation effect on the immune system in mice.

Secondly, I worked in Dr Shawn Campagna group in Chemistry department. Until I joined his lab I had never considered myself in a chemistry laboratory. I attempted to quantify lipids with LC-MS. Rotation had to end when I was very close to getting the product.
Thirdly, I worked in to be my home lab. I am challenged by identifying CheW role in chemotaxis.
In my final rotation, I worked with Dr. Mike Langston in the department of electrical engineering and computer science. Here, I learned about graph theory and clique analysis.
Rotations were great opportunity to select the lab that I was going to work for during Ph.D. When I look back, I feel glad to choose Igor's group as my home lab..

timeline.title: Teaching
timeline.text: I was a teaching assistant of the General Genetics class at UT for 5 semesters. I lead the discussion sections. I worked with Dr. Albrecht von Arnim, Dr. Bruce McKee, Dr. Andreas Nebenf√ºhr, Dr. Su Chunlei and Dr. Ben Keck. I also developed discussion section curriculum when adapting to a new text book.

timeline.title: Oak Ridge National Laboratory
text: This was the time that my research skills start to improve exponentially, as I became a research assistant. Though, I enjoyed teaching so far, I enjoyed to focus on only research, with no teaching reqiurements.
Our lab got a new space in ORNL. Though we kept the lab in UT, ORNL became our primary research space.

timeline.title: PhD defense
timeline.text: It was one of the most comfortable talks in my career. Just think about it: you know your stuff more than anyone in the world. Why wouldn't you be the most comfortable person then?

timeline.title: Postdoctoral Fellowship
timeline.text: The student life ends here, and a new chapter begins.

research.name: Protein Domains
research.text: Domains help us understand protein function and origin. Statistical models (matrices or HMMs) work well in representing domains. Domain identification in proteins is one of my interests as they can define proteins. Especially some complex proteins composed of multiple domains are identified based on their domain architectures. Specific domain combinations perform specific functions. Therefore, studies on domain architectures are helpful in revealing function and homology. Recently, model-to-model comparisons emerged as a sensitive method to identify remote homology.

research.name: Phylogenetics and Orthology
research.text: Orthologous genes are products of a same common ancestor and derived by a speciation event. Paralogs, on the other hand, are related through gene duplication in a current or an ancestral organism. Orthologous proteins tend to conserve the same function while paralogs likely diverge. Current orthology identification methods result in one-to-many orthologous relationships as well as one-to-one. In the case of one-to-one orthology, the picture is clear. However, one-to-many orthologs bring some problems in grouping functionally equivalent members. Phylogenetics is a great method to distinguish orthologs from paralogs. It is also powerful in distinguishing functionally equivalent groups within co-orthologs. I am interested in developing and applying the approach of functionally-equivalent orthologous identification.

research.name: Phylogenetic Profiling
research.text: Genes that work in the same biochemical pathway are found together in a genome. If functionally-interacting genes are mutually exclusive, they are also lost together in genomes that do not need the particular biochemical pathway process. Therefore, if observed, coevolution patterns of genes/proteins indicate a likelihood of functional interaction. I am interested in building large-scale phylogenetic profiles of orthologous groups. Profile-profile comparison of orthologous groups will indicate the likelihood of gene interaction.

research.name: Prokaryotic Signal Transduction
research.text: Genomics is a great field to study signal transduction in bacteria. As bacteria and archaea are simpler than eukaryotes, it is important to understand their signal transduction mechanisms to shed light to eukaryotes. Moreover, in targeting elements of signal transduction pathways in pathogens help in designing drugs to treat infections.

research.name: G Protein Coupled Receptors (GPCRs)
research.text: As the largest protein family in human, GPCRs attract scientists' attention. Though they are complex and diver diverse, they are well studied because of their potential in being drug targets. Approximately half of the current over counter medicines target one of our GPCRs. Despite being well studied, GPCRs still lack precisely defined characters in terms of functionally important and specific amino acids. My interest in GPCRs is to reveal these residues so that they can be targetted in receptor-specific drug design studies.

research.name: Missense Mutation Effects on Heath and Disease
research.text: In this genomics age, it became more important to increase the prediction accuracy on missense mutation effects. Benefiting from the evolutionary history of genes, it is possible to accurately estimate the effect of mutations on individuals' health for genetic diseases. We have shown that case-by-case approach substantially improves the overall performance of the estimation. I am interested in working manually on unlike Mendelian diseases before setting up a better automated tool.

basics.name: Ogun Adebali
basics.label: Computational Geneticist
basics.summary: Ogun Adebali is a geneticist by training. After he moved to Knoxville, he decided to switch his method of understanding molecular biology and dived into computational research. During his Ph.D., he minored in computer science and gained programming skills. At Oak Ridge National Laboratory, he had an opportunity to utilize high-performance clusters. He still conceives problems as a biologist, but he solves them via computers. He enjoys developing biologist-friendly tools as well as analyzing data. service.name: CDvist - Comprehensive Domain Visualization Tool
service.text: Protein domain identification is a highly important step in understanding the molecular function of proteins. Various domain search tools have strengths and weakness based on their properties. Some of them are  specific and others are sensitive. CDvist combines these tools in a logical pipeline to address the sensitivity problem with a minimum cost of specificity. CDvist is the only web server that provides batch requests (up to 500) for computationally intensive HHM-HMM comparison.

service.name: Aquerium - Architecture Querying Podium
service.text: One of computational methods to reveal or support protein-protein interactions is phylogenetic profiling. Cooccurences of proteins are indicators of functional interaction. Aquerium is a web-server to visualize co-presence/absence of any biological marker in genomes. It also provides a database of pre-computed and genome-linked domains to query domain architectures of interest.

service.name: SAVER (NPC1) - Single Amino Acid Variant Evaluator
service.text: Orthologs and paralogs have different roles in disease. However, current tools do not take this fact into account and do not distinguish them when evaluating the effect of a substitution on health. We think that only orthologs should be considered to have identical function. SAVER is an algorithm that uses several sets (such as orthologs and orthologs after most recent duplication) to evaluate the effects of single amino acid substitutions. This web server shows the results of a test case: effects of missense NPC1 mutations on Niemann-Pick disease type-C. The source code of SAVER is also available.

workbench_intro: The tools presented here are just to give idea of what we can do about visualizing the biological data on web. They are neither stable nor guaranteed for a scientific analysis. However, I am open to develop them if I see enough interest. Please contact with me if you feel like they can be useful to you.

effort.name: BlastCover
effort.text: One important missing ring in BLAST visualization chain is the coverage display. Knowing how much and what portion of your query actually aligns with the subject (hit) is important. This is an attempt of visualizing coverage of the query and subject. It takes CSV (BLAST results) as an input by default.

effort.name: OrthologyCrossfilter
effort.text: In genomics, instant filtering the data may play a crucial role in making sense out of the patterns. This is a javascript crossfilter example on Human-Chimpanzee one-to-one orthologs and some markers of my interests. It is extremely simple to use: it takes CSV as an input. However, it hasn't been generalized to address any CSV yet. Let me know if you are interested in a general version of this tool.

effort.name: CSVtoHTMLtable
effort.text: Web-based visualization is becoming more and more glaring. Therefore, although Excel or R are good for tables, they lack in creating custom graphics. HTML SVG helps here. This tool converts your table to HTML by adding another column for custom visualization. In principle any custom graph built based on the column values can be created.

effort.name: TreeArch
effort.text: Phylogenetic trees can be enriched in various information. One of the additional information that I wanted to retrieve was domain architectures. We only need to have a json formatted sequence file along with the newick. Domain architectures are retrieved from the SeqDepot database. One deficiency of this approach is the fact that the protein sequences that are not present in SeqDepot cannot be represented with a domain architecture figure.

effort.name: Treelign
effort.text: Displaying the alignment and phylogenetic tree together is undoubtedly very handy. All we need is newick and JSON formatted sequence file. Fasta2Json script can be found in my scripts collection in BitBucket.

effort.name: PhyloBlast
effort.text: Order of the BLAST results and their phyletic distribution can be useful. This tool enables one by one visualizing blast results on a phylogenetic tree and displays scores, e-values, and coverage information as well as the domain architecture. Please pay attention where a big gap in the e-value visual is introduced. Can that cutoff be used to determine the homolog sequences?

effort.name: BlastSnap
effort.text: This tool shows the blast hits aligned with a phyletic tree. X-axis is the hit number starts with the first hit and ends up with the last hit. I believe, this tool may potentially show horizontal gene transfers, contamination as well as a line of evidence for vertical evolution.

effort.name: TaxaSunburst
effort.text: This tool is the basic building block of the Aquerium visualization. Sunburst is a great way to show the taxonomic distribution of genomic entities. Zoomable sunburst was customized based on a d3 example and enabled outer non-hierarchical layers.

effort.name: TaxaCollapsable
effort.text: Taxonomic hierarchy is coupled by additional information on the domain architectures. This can be useful to identify taxomic lineage specific domain architecture.

effort.name: TreeRep
effort.text: Reducing redundacy in sequence sets is an important process to be able to retrieve a representative subset. This tool takes a phylogenetic tree as an input and outputs the representative sequences by considering their evolutionary relationships.

effort.name: Dared
effort.text: When searching 'similar' protein sequences wtih BLAST or PSI-BLAST, it would be useful to visualize the domain architectures of the hits to make sure that the hit is really similar to your query. In many cases only partial of the hit is similar to the query. Especially in PSI-BLAST deciding on whther to include the hit in the next iteration is critical. Displaying the domain organizations will help to decide if the hit is not a false positive. Dared (Domain ArchitectuRe EnhanceD) search is a chome extension that can be used when visualizing the blast results in the NCBI web site.
